name: Bhatura
history: Bhatura is a popular North Indian bread, particularly in Punjabi cuisine. It is often associated with the famous dish 'Chole Bhature'. The fluffy, deep-fried bread's origins are believed to be in the Punjab region.
description: Bhatura is a leavened, deep-fried bread made from maida (refined flour). It puffs up to become light and airy when fried, and is commonly served with spicy chickpeas (chole). Bhatura is known for its soft, chewy texture and slightly tangy flavor.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: In a large bowl, mix maida, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and yogurt. Gradually add warm water and knead into a soft dough. Add 2 tablespoons of oil and knead again. Cover the dough and let it rest for 2-3 hours.

instructions.title: Roll and Fry the Bhaturas
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Roll each ball into a thin, circular shape. Heat oil in a deep frying pan. Deep-fry each bhatura until it puffs up and turns golden brown on both sides.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the hot bhaturas with chole (spicy chickpeas) or any other curry.

tips: The dough should be soft and pliable for the best texture.
Ensure the oil is hot enough before frying for perfect puffing.
variations: Add spices like carom seeds (ajwain) or cumin seeds to the dough for a flavorful twist.
Stuff with spiced potatoes or paneer for a filling meal.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh and hot. Not recommended for storage.
storage.instructions: If necessary, keep in an airtight container for a few hours.

reheatingInstructions: Reheating is not recommended as it may alter the texture.
presentationTips: Serve on a platter with a side of fresh sliced onions and lemon wedges.
Accompany with a mint or tamarind chutney for added flavor.
